doc.title: Epic 6: Admin UI & Configuration Management
doc.snippet: Goal: Provide web-based admin interface for system visibility and configuration management. Value: Enable operations teams to manage tenant configurations, monitor system health, and view enhancement history without requiring kubectl access. Technologies: Streamlit 1.30+, Pandas, Plotly, SQLAlchemy (shared with FastAPI). Prerequisites: Epic 1-5 complete (MVP v1.0 validated in production).

doc.title: Functional Requirements - Admin UI & Configuration Management
doc.snippet: FR026: System shall provide web-based admin UI for configuration management and system visibility. FR027: Admin UI shall display real-time system status dashboard with key metrics. FR028: Admin UI shall provide tenant management interface for CRUD operations. FR029: Admin UI shall allow operators to view and filter enhancement history. FR030: Admin UI shall expose controls for system operations. FR031: Admin UI shall display worker health and resource utilization metrics.

doc.title: ADR-009: Streamlit for Admin UI
doc.snippet: Decision: Use Streamlit 1.30+ for the admin/operations UI (Epic 6). Rationale: Python-native (no context switching), 5-10x faster than React, built-in components, beginner-friendly, perfect fit for ops tools. Implementation: Separate Streamlit app (src/admin/app.py) independent of FastAPI, shared database access via SQLAlchemy, Kubernetes deployment on port 8501, authentication via Kubernetes Ingress + basic auth (MVP) with OAuth future upgrade path.

doc.title: Technology Stack - Admin UI Framework
doc.snippet: Admin UI Framework: Streamlit (Latest 1.30+) for Epic 6. Rationale: Python-native, rapid prototyping, built-in components, beginner-friendly, 5-10x faster than React. Source: Streamlit Docs + Sprint Change Proposal 2025-11-02.

doc.title: Project Structure - Admin UI Module
doc.snippet: src/admin/ module contains: app.py (Streamlit main app), pages/ (1_Dashboard.py, 2_Tenants.py, 3_History.py for multi-page navigation), utils/ (database.py for DB connection, metrics.py for metrics fetching helpers). Follows existing pattern: src/{component}/ organization with shared database access via SQLAlchemy.

doc.title: Authenticate Users and Personalize Your App
doc.snippet: Streamlit supports user authentication with the OpenID Connect (OIDC) protocol. You can use any OIDC provider including Google Auth Platform and Microsoft Entra for social and business logins. Authentication enables personalized user experiences and access control for admin applications.

doc.title: Deploy Streamlit using Kubernetes
doc.snippet: Kubernetes deployment requires: Dockerfile with entrypoint script, container registry (GCR), YAML configuration with Deployment and Service resources, oauth2-proxy sidecar for authentication (optional), resource limits (CPU/memory), health check probes (/_stcore/health endpoint), TLS support for production. Default port: 8501. LoadBalancer or Ingress for external access.

doc.title: Epic 6 Prioritization and Planning Context
doc.snippet: Epic 6 (Admin UI): RICE Score 90.0 - MUST-DO priority (highest of all future epics). Target: Q4 2025 (4 weeks, 8 stories). Reach: 100% of operations team (5 users daily). Impact: High (3/3) - critical operational capability. Confidence: High (90%) - proven Streamlit technology. Effort: 4 weeks (20 story points). Dependencies: Epic 1 complete (database models), Epic 4 complete (Prometheus metrics), Production validated (MVP v1.0 operational).

artifact.reason: SQLAlchemy model for tenant_configs table. MUST REUSE for Streamlit admin UI tenant management. Fields: id (UUID), tenant_id (unique), name, servicedesk_url, encrypted credentials, enhancement_preferences (JSON), rate_limits (JSON), timestamps. This is the single source of truth for tenant data - do not duplicate.

SQLAlchemy model for enhancement_history table. MUST REUSE for Streamlit history viewer. Fields: id (UUID), tenant_id (indexed), ticket_id (indexed), status (pending/completed/failed), context_gathered (JSON), llm_output, error_message, processing_time_ms, timestamps. Composite index on (tenant_id, ticket_id) for efficient lookups. Read-only access for admin UI.

Async SQLAlchemy session factory using asyncpg. Current implementation uses async patterns. Streamlit requires SYNCHRONOUS database access. Solution: Create NEW synchronous helper in src/admin/utils/db_helper.py using psycopg2 (not asyncpg) OR use sync_engine from sqlalchemy. DO NOT modify existing async session - it's used by FastAPI.

Reference pattern for Kubernetes Deployment. Follow same structure for streamlit-admin-deployment.yaml: namespace (ai-agents), labels (app/component), replicas, securityContext (runAsNonRoot), env vars from ConfigMap/Secret, resource limits, Prometheus annotations. Use RollingUpdate strategy with maxSurge=1, maxUnavailable=0.

Reference pattern for Kubernetes Ingress. Follow same structure for streamlit-admin-ingress.yaml: namespace (ai-agents), ingressClassName (nginx), host pattern (*.ai-agents.local for dev), pathType (Prefix). ADD AUTHENTICATION: nginx.ingress.kubernetes.io/auth-type: basic, auth-secret annotations per AC#4. Pattern shows TLS config (commented) for future production use.

Reference for app-config ConfigMap structure. Streamlit will need NEW ConfigMap for .streamlit/config.toml settings (theme, server port 8501, browser.gatherUsageStats=false, server.headless=true). Mount as volume in deployment at /home/appuser/.streamlit/

constraints.constraint: MUST reuse existing SQLAlchemy models (TenantConfig, EnhancementHistory) from src/database/models.py - no duplication or schema changes allowed
MUST create synchronous database connection helper - existing src/database/session.py uses async patterns incompatible with Streamlit's sync execution model
Follow existing Kubernetes manifest patterns: namespace (ai-agents), labels (app/component), securityContext (runAsNonRoot, user 1000), resource limits, Prometheus annotations
Streamlit runs on port 8501 (standard) - no conflicts with existing services (API: 8000, Grafana: 3000, Prometheus: 9090)
Use Kubernetes Ingress basic auth for MVP authentication (AC#4) - no additional Python libraries required, simpler than OAuth2-Proxy for initial deployment
Admin UI has read-only access to enhancement_history, read-write access to tenant_configs - no access to other tables (ticket_history, system_inventory) in Story 6.1
Follow project structure pattern: src/admin/ (app.py, pages/, utils/) mirrors existing src/ structure (api/, database/, workers/)
Tests must mirror source: tests/admin/ matches src/admin/ - use pytest with mocking for Streamlit components (st.session_state, st.cache_resource)
MUST follow CLAUDE.md standards: PEP8, type hints, docstrings (Google style), Black formatting, files <500 lines
Authentication decision per ADR-009: Start with Kubernetes Ingress basic auth, document OAuth2-Proxy upgrade path for production enterprise SSO

Coverage target: >80% for src/admin/ directory. For Streamlit-specific testing: Mock st.session_state dict, mock st.cache_resource decorator, mock database connections with pytest fixtures. Use pytest-mock for Streamlit component mocking. Test structure: tests/admin/test_app_startup.py (app initialization), tests/admin/test_db_helper.py (database helpers), tests/admin/test_authentication.py (auth logic). Manual testing required: Launch app locally with 'streamlit run src/admin/app.py', navigate pages, verify Kubernetes deployment with 'kubectl apply' and ingress access.
